text.headline: Califonia Beaches Grinnell Journal <small>Michele Tobias' study site journal</small>
text.text:
This map shows the locations of journal entries for Michele Tobias' dissertation work documenting the state of California's foredune vegetation from 2007-2011.

Learn more about Michele's work at her research website. Learn more about Joseph Grinnell's journalling method with Herman, Steven G. 1986. The Naturalist’s Field Journal: A Manual of Instruction Based on a System Established by Joseph Grinnell. Vermillion, South Dakota: Buteo Books.

media.caption: A relatively unimpacted beach in southern California

text.headline: Leo Carrillo State Park
text.text:
Date: June 18, 2007

Time: 0900-1600

Location: The southern beach at Leo Carrillo State Park, located on Highway 1 near the county line between Ventura and Los Angeles Counties, just north of Malibu.

Route: Frans Krajenbrink and I parked in the parking lot and walked under the highway and to the beach area south of the mouth of Arroyo Sequit. We set up the transects running from high water line to the back of the beach which corresponded with the edge of the cement pad for the showers and facilities.

Weather: Warm and sunny.

Habitat: Beach and foredune hillocks with coastal sage scrub towards the back of the beach and road area.

Vegetation: The beach vegetation was mainly beach bur with a few other species.

General Commentary: I observed a few European rocket plants very near the high water line, but they were very small and didn’t fall in any transects. The prickly beach bur seems to be doing better, maybe because no one wants to walk on them barefoot. People have built bunkers into the foredunes lined with the rocks that occur on the beach. The edges of these are typically vegetated with beach bur. Farther up on the beach, iceplant eradication seems to be going on. Where the iceplant has been removed, upland species are replacing it. I wonder if the plants at the back of the beach are affected by the freshwater coming from the showers that runs off the pad into the vegetation.

Species:

Common NameScientific Name
Beach BurAmbrosia chamissonis
MugwortArtemisia douglasiana
Coyote Brush Baccharis pilularis
MulefatBaccharis salicifolia
European RocketCakile maritima
Iceplant (yellow) Carpobrotus sp.
Canadian Horseweed Conyza canadensis
Distichlis (?) Distichlis spicata
Telegraph Weed Heterotheca grandiflora
Sweet Clover Melilotus officinalis
Fountain Grass Pennisetum setacetum
Chickweed Malacothrix saxatilis
Bush Sunflower Encelia californica
Field Mustard Brassica rapa
grasses

media.caption: a stitched aerial image of the east side of Leo Carrillo

text.headline: Ormond Beach & Sycamore Cove
text.text:
Date: June 19, 2007

Time: 0830-1130

Location: Ormond Beach is located south of Port Hueneme and immediately north of Point Mugu Naval Air Weapons Station. The southern extent of this beach is marked by Arnold Road, which is off of Hueneme Road in Oxnard. Sycamore Cove is off of Highway 1 and is a part of Point Mugu State Park.

Route:This was mainly a driving tour in which Frans Krajenbrink and I were investigating potential sampling sites. We drove to Ormond Beach first and parked in the southern lot for Hueneme Beach. Then we drove to Sycamore Cove and walked around the picnic area, investigating the vegetation that was there.

Weather: Unrecorded

Habitat: Beach with hillocks of vegetation including a picnic area and parking lot.

Vegetation: The vegetation at Ormond was unrecorded at this time because of a sign warning of western snowy plovers. At Sycamore Cove, much of the vegetation here was impacted heavily by humans. There were many planted species including iceplant, podocarpus, and eucalyptus. The edge of the parking area was lined with the expected ruderals.

General Commentary: At Sycamore Cove, the vegetation is sparse and limited to islands. This situation would require a different sampling strategy because it looks like transects would miss islands easily. In addition, if they did cross the islands, the current sampling procedure would over estimate cover. I believe there is also beach bur and a sand verbena at this beach, but they weren’t recorded originally because the stop was short.

Species: note: species recalled from memory a year later – this list is by no means exhaustive.

Common NameScientific Name
IceplantCarpobrotus sp
EucalyptusEucalyptus sp
Podocarpus Podocarpus sp
